instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v ub400 getting hot
threads.message:
working on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that was working but had failed usb port, replaced the bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (ub300) but had no power after, replaced ub400 still no power, chips i was using were bought online, figured maybe the was bad, so i pulled chips from donor board and reballed, 
anyhow after spending most of the day Sunday on it i have restored 5v to all ports with .45amps, but UB400 i getting hot,  both ub400 and ub300 have been replaced 4-5x  cant seem to figure this out, cant seem to locate short on any of the LDO lines or surrounding components, qb300/qb4000 <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and rom chip have also been replaced

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v ub400 getting hot
threads.message:
First inspect for knocked off components.
Compare diode mode readings on LDO lines between all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v ub400 getting hot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> .0009 CB408
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> .0013 CB405
seems UB400 might be shorted again, very strange  i have replaced chip 4 times, could something else be blowing the chips after replacing

replaced CB400 again, ldo readings are normal again back to  5v .28amp
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> .470 CB408
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> .516 CB405
<SIGNAL>PPV1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> .516 CB404

these ldos seem a bit low compared to working board but not shorted 
<CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> .347
<RESISTOR>R3208</RESISTOR> .347
<RESISTOR>R3209</RESISTOR> .347

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v ub400 getting hot
threads.message:
Do you get 1V1 LDO on the powered port?
Check on each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v ub400 getting hot
threads.message: yea <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> is present on all 4 ports. was missing on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, replaced chip and restored 1v1 ldo but still no power, 5.14v .26amp on all ports

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v ub400 getting hot
threads.message:
If the board was working before, I can only suspect bad chips, bad solders, or broken trace.
Considering you've discarded knocked off components.
